thread.title: Cowboys' Morris Claiborne: Seeing how coaches study film has paid off
thread.title_full: Cowboys' Morris Claiborne: Seeing how coaches study film has paid off | Dallas Morning News

author: Jon Machota
title: Cowboys' Morris Claiborne: Seeing how coaches study film has paid off
text:
IRVING -- Although Morris Claiborne missed 12 regular season games and the playoffs because of a torn patellar tendon, he doesn't look at last season as a complete loss.
While rehabbing from the injury, Claiborne became a better student of the game.
"That's a big thing that I've really learned," Claiborne said. "Just sitting down with the coaches when I was sitting out, going in and seeing how they study film and learning the correct way to study film."
Before that extra time with Cowboys staff members like defensive backs coach Jerome Henderson, Claiborne says he would just turn on the film, watch plays and call that film study, not really knowing what to look for.
"But now I take the breakdowns of the top concepts and things like that and go in-depth with it, down and distances and formations," Claiborne said.
"I think any time a young player comes into this league, the level of learning has to increase," Cowboys coach Jason Garrett said. "I think he understands that he goes against really good players, understanding the guy he's playing against, their technique, understanding schemes, but maybe more than anything else being able to watch himself and being able to understand what he's doing technically and also from an assignment standpoint."
Through three games, the Cowboys' starting right cornerback is seeing the fruits of his labor. In last Sunday's loss to Atlanta, Claiborne was Dallas' best when it came to defending Julio Jones.
Claiborne was in coverage on Jones for eight targets, most of any Cowboys defender. Claiborne held the two-time Pro Bowler to four catches for 41 yards.
"I think he is playing really good," Cowboys defensive coordinator Rod Marinelli said. "I mean he is playing really good man-to-man technique. And he is tackling, making plays. We're pleased with where he's at."
